input_prompt:
Extract all factual claims from this YouTube transcript:

If, for the same work, women make only 77 cents for every dollar a man makes, why don’t businesses hire only women? Wages are the biggest expense for most businesses. So, hiring only women would reduce costs by nearly a quarter – and that would go right to the bottom line. Don’t businesses want to be profitable? Or, are they just really bad at math? Well, actually, it’s the feminists, celebrities and politicians spreading this wage gap myth who have the math problem. Here’s why: The 77-cents-on-the-dollar statistic is calculated by dividing the median earnings of all women working full-time by the median earnings of all men working full-time. In other words, if the average income of all men is, say, 40,000 dollars a year, and the average annual income of all women is, say, 30,800 dollars, that would mean that women earn 77 cents for every dollar a man earns. 30,800 divided by 40,000 equals .77. But these calculations don’t reveal a gender wage injustice because it doesn’t take into account occupation, position, education or hours worked per week. Even a study by the American Association of University Women, a feminist organization, shows that the actual wage gap shrinks to only 6.6 cents when you factor in different choices men and women make. And the key word here is “choice.” The small wage gap that does exist has nothing to do with paying women less, let alone with sexism; it has to do with differences in individual career choices that men and women make. In 2009, the U.S. Department of Labor released a paper that examined more than 50 peer-reviewed studies and concluded that the oft-cited 23 percent wage gap “may be almost entirely the result of individual choices being made by both male and female workers.” Well, let’s look at some of those choices. Georgetown University compiled a list of the five best-paying college majors, and the percentage of men or women majoring in those fields: Number 1 best-paying major: Petroleum Engineering: 87% male Number 2: Pharmaceutical Sciences: 48% male 3: Mathematics and Computer Science: 67% male 4: Aerospace Engineering: 88% male 5: Chemical Engineering: 72% male Notice that women out-represent men in only one of the five top-paying majors – by only a few percentage points. Now consider the same study’s list of the five worst paying college majors: Number 1: Counseling and Psychology: 74% female Number 2: Early Childhood Education: 97% female 3: Theology and Religious Vocations: 66% male 4: Human Services and Community Organization: 81% female 5: Social Work: 88% female Here, it’s the women who lead in all but one category. Even within the same profession, men and women make different career choices that impact how much money they make. Take nursing, where male nurses on the whole earn 18% more than female nurses. The reason? Male nurses gravitate to the best-paying nursing specialties, they work longer hours, and disproportionately find jobs in cities with the highest compensation. Now, here’s how one expert on nursing compensation, Professor Linda Aiken of the University of Pennsylvania, sums up the data: “Career choices and educational differences explain most, if not all, the gender gap in nursing.” The Department of Labor paper concluded that once these differences are accounted for across all professions, the unexplained wage gap is somewhere between 4.8 and 7 percent – almost identical to the 6.6 percentage gap found by the AAUW. But why is there any gap at all? No one knows for sure, as both the AAUW and the Labor Department concede. There are so many variables that drive wages that no single study can cover them all. Few wage gap studies control for variables such as dangerous work environment; men are vastly overrepresented, for example, on oil rigs. And here’s another variable: men are more willing and able to work long hours without advance notice. According to Harvard economist Claudia Goldin, even if two lawyers have the same education, same specialty, and work the same number of hours — firms pay more to someone who is willing to always be “on call” and ready to be in the office when the firm needs them, as opposed to wanting a more regular schedule. This isn’t sexism, it’s just common sense. With more realistic categories and definitions, whatever wage gap remains would certainly narrow to point of vanishing. So it seems that business leaders aren’t bad at math simply because they don’t only hire women. Those who claim that for the same work women earn 77 cents on the dollar compared to men, on the other hand, are not merely bad at math --but at telling the truth. I’m Christina Hoff Sommers of the American Enterprise Institute for Prager University.

claims.text: In 2009, the U.S. Department of Labor released a paper that examined more than 50 peer-reviewed studies and concluded that the 23 percent wage gap may be almost entirely the result of individual choices.

claims.text: Georgetown University compiled a list of the five best-paying college majors, showing 87% male in Petroleum Engineering.

claims.context: Claim about remaining wage gap, speaker: Christina Hoff Sommers

input_prompt:
Claim: Men are vastly overrepresented on oil rigs, which are dangerous work environments.
Category: statistical
Extraction confidence: 0.80

Evidence:
SUPPORTS (1 sources):
  1. Manly Men, Oil Platforms, and Breaking Stereotypes - Baker Library | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://www.library.hbs.edu/working-knowledge/manly-men-oil-platforms-and-breaking-stereotypes
     Summary: The article discusses how men dominate dangerous work environments, such as oil rigs, and how this can lead to behaviors that may increase risk, supporting the claim of their overrepresentation in such settings.
UNCLEAR (4 sources):
  1. Danger zone: Men, masculinity and occupational health and safety ... | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4880472/
     Summary: In general, men have demonstrated that they are more likely than women to engage in risky activities, such as smoking, alcohol overuse and unsafe sexual ...
  2. Occupational Safety and Health of Women in Mining - PMC | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11152354/
     Summary: Furthermore, recent research indicates that women in mining are at a higher risk of developing a work-related MSD than men (73% vs. 54.3%).
  3. Women's experiences working in the oil and gas industry in Canada | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S2214790X21000277
     Summary: Women remain vastly underrepresented in the oil and gas workforce. As such, they are subject to gender-based discrimination and harassment, perpetuated by a ...
  4. How male oil rig staff learned to lose their machismo | BPS | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://www.bps.org.uk/research-digest/how-male-oil-rig-staff-learned-lose-their-machismo
     Summary: "Dangerous workplaces provide a window on how processes associated with masculinity unfold in organisations."

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that men are overrepresented on oil rigs, with a high-reliability source indicating that men dominate these dangerous work environments, which can lead to increased risk behaviors.

input_prompt:
Claim: Women make only 77 cents for every dollar a man makes.
Category: statistical
Extraction confidence: 0.90

Evidence:
UNCLEAR (4 sources):
  1. Did You Know That Women Are Still Paid Less Than Men? | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/equal-pay/myth
     Summary: On average, full-time working women earn just 78 cents for every dollar a man earns. This significant gap is more than a statistic -- it has real life ...
  2. Gender pay gap in U.S. has narrowed slightly over 2 decades | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/03/04/gender-pay-gap-in-us-has-narrowed-slightly-over-2-decades/
     Summary: The gender gap in pay has slightly narrowed in the United States over the past 20 years or so. In 2024, women earned an average of 85% of what men earned.
  3. Equal pay for work of equal value | UN Women – Headquarters | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://www.unwomen.org/en/news/in-focus/csw61/equal-pay
     Summary: Worldwide, women only make 77 cents for every dollar earned by men. As a result, there's a lifetime of income inequality between men and women.
  4. Explaining the Gender Wage Gap - Center for American Progress | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://www.americanprogress.org/article/explaining-the-gender-wage-gap/
     Summary: The most commonly cited statistic for the gender wage gap asserts that women earn only 77 cents for every dollar earned by men.

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: The claim that women make only 77 cents for every dollar a man makes is supported by some sources, such as the UN Women report and the Center for American Progress, which cite this statistic. However, other sources indicate that the figure is higher, with women earning 78 cents or 85 cents per dollar in different contexts. This discrepancy suggests a mixed understanding of the gender pay gap.

     Summary: GAO defined less- educated workers as those having a high school degree or less and low- wage workers as those earning an hourly wage rate in ...

output.summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim. While some sources, like the AEI report, suggest that individual choices may largely explain the wage gap, other high-reliability sources indicate that factors such as firm inequality and discrimination also play significant roles.      Summary: In 2015, the pay gap clocked in at 77 cents for 45- to 54-year-olds and 74 cents for 55- to 64-year-olds. Here's how to think about what's ...

     URL: https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2025/03/04/gender-pay-gap-in-us-has-narrowed-slightly-over-2-decades/
     Summary: The gender pay gap measures the difference in median hourly earnings between men and women who work full or part time in the United States.

  6. [PDF] THE NOT SO SIMPLE TRUTH - AAUW | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://www.aauw.org/app/uploads/2025/03/The_Simple_Truth_Gender_Pay_Gap_2025.pdf
     Summary: The pay gap is the difference in men's and women's median earnings, usually reported as the earnings ratio between men and women. The median ...

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the calculation of the 77-cents-on-the-dollar statistic. While several sources confirm that it is calculated by dividing women's median earnings by men's median earnings (e.g., Economic Policy Institute), others highlight that the statistic may not fully capture the complexities of the gender wage gap, which can be influenced by various factors beyond simple earnings comparisons.
